page.title: 05Ecology of the Alford area
page.content: The land is well cultivated so only fragments of wild habitats survive. These include the River Don flowing fast and clean, the home of salmon and trout where herons, otters and osprey fish and dippers hunt. Wet corners of fields, gardens and many amenity and shelter belts provide small wildlife refuges. Murray and Haughton Parks are bigger birchwoods containing scattered Scots pine, oak, ash, elm, elder, rowan, alder, gean and planted conifers and exotic specimen trees. Ancient woodland indicators (chick- weed wintergreen, wood anenome and wood sorrel) show that these woods have never been cultivated. The farmland supports large numbers of rabbits and hares and feeds some of the biggest flocks of rooks in Britain and Common Gulls whose nearby nesting colonies are the biggest in Britain.
